ratings.comment: Lots of reading - about a book per week. The material is interesting for the most part and Prof. Koshar is very knowledgeable about the topics, especially pertaining to German History. Overall a good class - can be a bit dry at times.
Rambles about useless topics and he has a very unclear grading standard.

Mind-expanding class. Lectures might seem disorganized sometimes but that's just how history classes are; you're supposed to figure it out for yourself sometimes. You might think there's a lot to read, but, secretly, you can get an A without reading everything. Also: the man knows SO MANY THINGS. You'll be amazed, entertained and educated.

Prof. Koshar is easy to understand & keeps your attention well.  He is extremely knowledgeable & has interesting stories but doesn't let them overrun the material. There is a lot of reading involved but the books  are way more interesting than ones I have read for any other class. I definitely recommend any class with him.
Interesting class. Involved many social, political, and philosophical movements. Great books, easy to read. Not about popular culture, course title a bit misleading.
The best class I have taken! He goes into a lot of depth without overwhelming you. If you show up to class and read the primary sources it isn't hard to do well.
Not well organized. Lectures difficult to follow. Likes intellectual trends but does not provide proper framework or chronology.

Awful lecturer, rambles on and on about topics that aren't important (like prior professors that he worked with), lectures have no clear theme and this class is way more work than a 3 credit class should be, by far the most reading I've had to do and I'm a history major, plus he would mention an entire for 2 seconds in class, do not take.

He teaches the class as though you signed up for a culture class, not a history class.  literally spent half a lecture on WWI.  Rambles about useless topics.  Lectures never end.  Has spent 2 lectures talking about German architecture alone. NOT the class I thought I was signing up for.  Very disappointed.

He is a very friendly guy. He assigns a ton of reading and you will read like 6 books. They are very interesting however. The lectures only seem to supplement the reading materials decently. And the lectures can be pretty boring. Nonetheless, i learned a ton about religious though from 1800-1950.  Hard class but rewarding

Spectacular professor. Very knowledgeable and lectures are interesting. However, lecture material is never used in assignments. Paper prompts were very vague and unclear and were entirely reading based. If you do all of the readings you'll do alright. Very few people receive A's, but you won't encounter a better historian
GREAT professor. This man deserves so much respect. One of the most knowledgable historians I've ever encountered. Very approachable outside of class. He will get you interested in the material.

Worst lectures ever. He would babble on for 50 minutes and no one had any idea what he was even talking about. He acts like everyone in the class has been studying the history of theology for years. He is VERY unclear about everything and the only way you can even write the papers is to attend discussion because he doesn't even address the topics!!
If German intellectual/cultural history is your interest, Dr. Koshar's class should be mandatory.  Well-read, published, and extremely knowledgeable.

Dr. Koshar was my senior thesis advisor. I had little background on the subject and even when I said the stupidest, most awkward things, he was still incomparably nice. Oh and he's insanely well-read on modern German history.
good class...i would recommend it to anyone--history majors or not.  relatively easy.  three papers.  no exams.
A very nice, approachable prof. Also, he has a profound knowledge of the subjects he teaches and more.

Koshar was a great professor & is a genius when it comes to Euro Hist. There was very little work for this class(3 papers & 2 tests)but having a good TA really does help. One word of caution, Koshar focuses heavilly on intellectual history & Germany,so those expecting to learn more on the battles of WWI and WWII will be dissapointed. Good class

This class is aboutEuropean Culture, not history. Look up the other classes that Koshar teaches.This class is a strange, abbreviated version of those. This European history class skipped over WWI, WWII, and the last 50 years. Also, there are several papers. You will learn about art movements in Europe, & have to read 7 books, as well as a textbook.

So this class is relatively easy - Really good TA's and an easy midterm with exam objectives and a list of ids given out prior to the midterm...and then you get to the final.  He handed out a list of possible essay questions and then told us that there were would be 5 ids which had never been covered in class and did not appear in the book :-(
he talked too much and it was unclear what we would be tested on because there was so much material given.

He's very knowledgable about the subjects he teaches but he presents his lectures with the same tone of voice that a priest delivers a sermon. If you're not really interested in History then you'll have a very hard time staying awake

The real name of this class should be "Intellectual History of Europe since 1870" NOT "European Cultural History Since 1870". All u talk about is intellectual movements, new ways of thinking & literature. Koshar is a genious & is a good prof but u better hope u get a good TA. Your TA will make or break this class 4u. LOTS of reading in this class.

Very clear and concise though may move a little quickly at times and use words that require a handy dandy little dictionary. Very helpful and challenging if actually go to office hours or make an attempt to meet with him. I found the reading for my particular semester a bit long and dry and long with exceptions--depends on the class I guess.

This class was extremely interesting and the reading load was actually pretty light. The lectures got a little boring and mundane, but his assignments are really creative and I actually had fun writing them! Definitely a recommendation for history majors!
Koshar is a walking encyclopedia, and talks like one too. The reading for this class is interesting, especially the novels. It was a lot of work, but well worth the effort.
Professor Koshar is the best. Not only is he a great teacher, he is also well published. Rudy Koshar rules!

this man is amazing...he knows absolutely everything about everything. his lectures are interesting and clearly organized. class description says writing intensive, but it's actually just one 50 word sentence per week and 3 papers. id highly recommend koshar...he is amazing!
